summary.value: This is a registration of secondary analyses on pooled data from two lab-based studies. The attached file contains the preregistration.

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of secondary analyses on pooled data from two lab-based studies. The attached file contains the preregistration.

q1.value: An investigation in the role of Mu oscillations in perspective-taking

q2.value: Jonathan Silas, Alexander Jones, Lola Zao-Sanders

q3.value:
To date, ample evidence exists describing the correlation between brain oscillations and cognitive functions, see Basar et al. (2001) for a comprehensive review. However, whether these oscillations have a causal role in mental processing or are simply epiphenomenal in their nature, remains undetermined. If cortical oscillations play a causal role in cognition, then an effect on any particular cognitive function should be observed when interfering with the oscillations underlying that function (Sejnowski & Paulsen, 2006). In this study, we propose a transcranial Alternating Current Stimulation (tACS) protocol to investigate the neural correlates of perspective-taking. In particular, we aim to determine whether Mu oscillations (~10Hz) in healthy adults play a role in embodied cognition as measured by performance in a perspective-taking task.

Mu desynchronisation has been observed in action observation, voluntary movement and somatosensory stimulation (Frenkel-Toledo et al, 2013; Canon et al, 2014). Although mu suppression has been linked to self-referential processing underlying embodied cognition, the precise role of central mu rhythms in facilitating self-referential processing remains unknown. This pre-registered investigation seeks to better understand the functional role of these rhythms in third-person perspective-taking. By applying tACS to the sensorimotor cortex, we aim to modulate mu activity whilst measuring the participants’ performance on a perspective-taking task. 

A recent study by Conson et al. (2015) investigated third-person perspective-taking and attributed faster rotation of back facing human figures, compared to front-facing ones, to an embodied processes in neurotypicals. 

The main purpose of this experiment is to test whether inhibiting mu suppression over the sensorimotor cortex will have an effect on embodied simulation performance in a neurotypical population and whether an interaction can be observed between stimulation frequency and stimuli facing direction as a result of mu modulation. 

All participants will be required to complete an online Autism-Spectrum Quotient (AQ) test. The AQ has the potential to classify three groups of people (low, average, and high degree of autistic traits)  (Lundqvist & Lindner, 2017). The AQ scores will be correlated with the two groups' mean reaction times for front and back-facing stimuli. Although this study focuses on a neurotypical population we aim to establish whether a relationship exists between the degree of autistic traits and the capacity for embodied cognition. We approach this by using a continuous measure of autistic traits and assuming that ASD is a dimensional construct (Baron-Cohen et al., 2001).

In addition, this study sets out to explore whether sex differences between the participant and the stimuli have an effect on how readily the participants shift their perspective. There are well-documented sex differences in mu desynchronisation during simulation (Silas et al., 2010; 2012) and familiarity with stimulus has also been shown to modulate simulation cortical networks (Calvo-Merino et al., 2005; 2006).

q4.value:
1.	Main effect of stimulation – 10Hz stimulation with result in slower RTs compared to 5.5Hz stimulation. 
4.	Main effect of facing direction – Facing direction will affect reaction times with faster RTs for back-facing stimuli compared to front-facing stimuli. 
3.	Main effect of orientation – Degree of stimuli rotation will affect RTs with faster RTs at 0ᵒ compared to all other orientations.
4.	Facing direction X stimulation – there will be a smaller difference in RTs between front and back-facing stimuli in 10Hz stimulation group compared to 5.5Hz condition. 
5.	Sex x Facing direction – there will be a greater difference in RTs of back-facing stimuli across congruent conditions compared to incongruent. 
6.	Sex x Facing X stimulation – there will be no bigger difference in front-back RTs between sex-matched condition in 10Hz compared to 5.5Hz. 
7.  AQ score x facing direction - given previous findings (Conson et al., 2015) we hypothesise that the difference between front- and back-facing stimuli RTs will decrease as the AQ scores increase.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Mixed between-subjects design with 4 factors and 10 levels (2x2x4x2)

Dependent variable: Reaction times

Factor 1: Stimulation frequency (10Hz/5.5Hz)
Factor 2: Facing direction (Front/Back)
Factor 3: Orientation (0/90/180/270)
Factor 4: Sex (same/different)

We estimate that any effect of interest should be at least medium (f = .25) working on an assumed power of 0.90 and expecting a key mixed interaction effect (2X2) we observe actual power of 0.91 with a total sample size of 46. 

Participants will be randomly allocated to the experimental (10Hz) or control (5.5Hz) condition and be blind to the type of stimulation they are receiving. The stimuli will be presented in 8 randomised blocks and the response keys counterbalanced across participants. See randomisation protocol attached for details. 

Each condition will be presented 4 times per orientation (4: 0, 90, 180, 270), facing direction (2: back, front), identity of stimuli (6 different people: 3 male, 3 female) and side of marked hand (2: left, right).  Resulting in 384 trials and 24 repetitions for each critical condition (collapsing across marked hand and identity but not sex).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be sampled opportunistically and will be mostly university students. 46 healthy adult participants will be recruited for the study and screened for suitability and eligibility for non-invasive brain stimulation. The participants will not be rewarded in any way for participating in the experiment. The participants will be allocated to either real or control condition in a counterbalanced fashion and provided with the tACS safety screen questionnaire adapted from transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) Adult Safety Screen (TASS) questionnaire (Keel, Smith, & Wassermann, 2001). In addition, the participants will be required to complete the online version of the Autism-Spectrum Quotient (AQ-10) test.

The participants will be assigned a number according to their order of entry into the experiment and be allocated to either the experimental or the control group. The participants will be unaware of whether they are receiving the experimental or control frequency during stimulation. To ensure the integrity of this blinding, the participants will be required to complete a questionnaire at the end of each session to determine the degree of confidence about whether they received the experimental or the control frequency.

The participants will have tACS applied bilaterally to locations C3 and C4 and a current of 1.5 mA, peak to peak (current density of 0.000043 μA/cm2) at a frequency of 10Hz in the real condition, and 5.5Hz in the control condition. Stimulation will start approximately 2 minutes before the behavioural paradigm in order to check the participant is comfortable and to allow for oscillatory entrainment.

Two 70 x 50mm rubber electrodes will be attached to the scalp and impedance will be reduced by applying 10/20 electrode paste to the electrodes at a thickness of approximately 0.5cm, making sure to avoid causing any discomfort to the participant. A DC-Stimulator Plus (neuroConn©) will be used to administer current to the brain. 

The experiment will consist of a series of images presented to the participants on a computer screen and the responses recorded using E-Prime software. Participants will be asked to perform an own-body transformation task by making a left/right judgement on a human figure facing towards or away from them. Participants will be instructed to imagine themselves in the place of the presented figure to determine which side of the figure’s hand is marked with a black dot. The stimuli will be presented on a screen and the participants instructed to manually respond by pressing the appropriate keys on the keyboard (counterbalanced across participants) once they have made their judgement. The reaction times will be recorded. The results will be analysed in terms of participants’ response times and error rates. 

Images are photographs of previous students at Middlesex University, taken with consent, and edited in Photoshop (CC - Adobe). The images had faces blurred, backgrounds were removed and the images were grey-scaled and matched for luminance. The final images used for the experiment were of 6 individuals (3 women and 3 men). Across the whole experiment, each individual image is presented eight times for each condition (4- orientation, 2 - facing). The order of presentation is randomised by the stimuli presentation software.  A break is given to participants after every 48 trials. See attached e-studio file for details. 

Data will be collected over a period of 4 months. In order to identify and exclude any participants who did not understand the instructions or fully engage with the task, any trials with RTs less than 100ms and more than 2.5 standard deviations of each participant’s mean RT for the task will be excluded from the final analysis.

q13.value: Our target sample is 46 participants. We will attempt to recruit 51, assuming not all will complete the experiment and that some data may be excluded from the final analysis.

q14.value: A-priori sample size estimation was conducted via a power analysis. Estimating that any effect of interest should be at least medium (f = .25) working on an assumed power of 0.90 and expecting a key mixed interaction effect (2X2) we observe actual power of 0.91 with a total sample size of 46.

question.value:
IV1: Stimulation frequency (10Hz, 5.5Hz)
IV2: Stimuli facing direction (Front, Back)
IV3: Stimuli orientation (0, 90, 180, 270)
IV4: Stimuli sex relative to participant (match/mismatch)
The two dependent variables are reaction times and error rates. The participants' score on the Autism Spectrum Quotient (Simon Baron-Cohen, 2001) will also be recorded.

We will take mean reaction times from correct responses and mean error rates. Any trials with RTs less than 100ms and more than 2.5 standard deviations of each participant’s mean RT for the task will be excluded from the mean. Participants who, after rejecting individual trials have less than usable 60% trials overall will be removed from the data set.

Two separate four-way mixed-analysis of variance (ANOVAs) will be conducted on RTs and error rates, with Stimuli Facing direction (front- and back-facing), Stimuli Sex (congruent, incongruent) and Stimuli Orientation (0, 90, 180, 270) as within-subject factors and with Group (experimental and control) as a between-subject factor. Below we outline the anticipated findings and analysis plan. The specific comparisons we intend to make are numbered to correspond with the numbering of the hypotheses in the study information section: 

1. Main effect of stimulation frequency with 10Hz stimulation resulting in slower RTs compared to 5.5Hz stimulation. 

2. Main effect of facing direction with faster RTs for back-facing stimuli compared to front-facing stimuli.

3. Main effect of orientation - the degree of stimuli rotation will have an effect on RTs with faster RTs at 0ᵒ compared to all other orientations. If a significant main effect is found, pairwise t-tests will be conducted between pairs of rotation angles.

4. Interaction between Facing Direction and Stimulation Frequency - we expect to find a smaller difference in RTs between front- and back-facing stimuli in 10Hz stimulation group compared to 5.5Hz condition. If a significant interaction effect is found, follow up analysis will include pairwise t-test between 10Hz and 5.5Hz groups of the mean difference in RTs between front- and back-facing stimuli. 

5. Interaction between Sex and Facing Direction – we expect to find a greater difference in  RTs of back minus front-facing stimuli in the matched condition compared to mismatched.  If a significant interaction effect is found, follow up analysis will include pairwise t-test between mean RTs of congruent and incongruent conditions. 

6. Interaction between Sex, Facing Direction and Stimulation – we expect to find no greater difference between RTs of congruent conditions in 10Hz compared to 5.5Hz. 
Follow up analyses will include two 2x2 ANOVAs of Sex and Facing Direction, separately for 10Hz and 5.5Hz. We expect to find a significant interaction in 10Hz and not in 5.5Hz. In 10Hz, the 2x2 interaction will be followed up by a pairwise t-test between the front minus back differences in RTs of congruent and incongruent conditions. 

7. Interaction between AQ score and facing direction - we expect to find slower reaction times for back-facing stimuli and a smaller difference between back and front-facing stimuli RTs across both groups associated with higher AQ scores. However, it should be noted that our participants are assumed to be neurotypical and therefore not much variability in AQ scores is anticipated. 

8. A Correlation between AQ score and RTs - AQ scores will have an effect on RTs. We expect to find a smaller difference in RTs between front and back facing-stimuli as the AQ score increases. Separate to the factorial design we will measure the correlation between AQ scores and front-back RTs for each individual group and across both groups.

q21.value: The standard p<.05 criteria will be used to determine significance.

q22.value: In order to identify and exclude any participants who did not understand the instructions or fully engage with the task any trials with RTs less than 100ms and more than 2.5 standard deviations of each participant’s mean RT for the task will be excluded from the final analysis.

q25.value:
Başar, E., Başar-Eroglu, C., Karakaş, S., and Schürmann, M. (2001). Gamma, alpha, delta, and theta oscillations govern cognitive processes. Int. J. Psychophysiol. 39, 241–248. doi: 10.1016/S0167-8760(00)00145-8

Bikson, M., Datta, A., & Elwassif, M. (2009). Establishing safety limits for transcranial direct current stimulation. Clinical neurophysiology: official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology, 120(6), 1033.

Bikson, M., Grossman, P., Thomas, C., Zannou, A. L., Jiang, J., Adnan, T., Woods, A. J. (2016). Safety of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation: Evidence Based Update 2016. Brain Stimulation. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.brs.2016.06.004 

Calvo-Merino, B., Glaser, D. E., Grèzes, J., Passingham, R. E. & Haggard, P. (2005) Action observation and acquired motor skills: an FMRI study with expert dancers. Cereb. Cortex 15, 1243–9. 

Calvo-Merino, B., Grèzes, J., Glaser, D. E., Passingham, R. E. & Haggard, P. (2006). Seeing or doing? Influence of visual and motor familiarity in action observation. Curr. Biol. 16, 1905–10. 

Cannon, E. N., Yoo, K. H., Vanderwert, R. E., Ferrari, P. F., Woodward, A. L., & Fox, N. A. (2014). Action experience, more than observation, influences mu rhythm desynchronization. Plos one, 9(3), e92002.

Conson, M., Mazzarella, E., Esposito, D., Grossi, D., Marino, N., Massagli, A., & Frolli, A. (2015). “Put myself into your place”: Embodied simulation and perspective taking in autism spectrum disorders. Autism Research, 8(4), 454-466.

Frenkel-Toledo, S., Bentin, S., Perry, A., Liebermann, D. G. & Soroker, N. Dynamics of the EEG power in the frequency and spatial domains during observation and execution of manual movements. Brain Res. 1509, 43–57 (2013).

Lundqvist, L. O., & Lindner, H. (2017). Is the autism-spectrum quotient a valid measure of traits associated with the autism spectrum? A Rasch validation in adults with and without autism spectrum disorders. Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders, 47(7), 2080-2091.

Sejnowski, T. J., and Paulsen, O. (2006). Network oscillations: emerging computational principles. J. Neurosci. 26, 1673–1676. doi: 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3737-05d.2006

Silas, J., Levy, J. P., Nielsen, M. K., Slade, L. & Holmes, A. (2010) Sex and individual differences in induced and evoked EEG measures of action observation. Neuropsychologia 48, 2417–26.

Silas, J., Levy, J. P. & Holmes, A. (2012) Sensitivity of ‘mu’ rhythm modulation to the relevance of an observed movement but not to goal congruency. Int. J. Psychophysiol. 6–11.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Mixed between-subjects design with 4 factors and 10 levels (2x2x4x2)

Dependent variable: Reaction times

Factor 1: Stimulation frequency (10Hz/5.5Hz)
Factor 2: Facing direction (Front/Back)
Factor 3: Orientation (0/90/180/270)
Factor 4: Sex (same/different)

We estimate that any effect of interest should be at least medium (f = .25) working on an assumed power of 0.90 and expecting a key mixed interaction effect (2X2) we observe actual power of 0.91 with a total sample size of 46. 

Participants will be randomly allocated to the experimental (10Hz) or control (5.5Hz) condition and be blind to the type of stimulation they are receiving. The stimuli will be presented in 8 randomised blocks and the response keys counterbalanced across participants. See randomisation protocol attached for details. 

Each condition will be presented 4 times per orientation (4: 0, 90, 180, 270), facing direction (2: back, front), identity of stimuli (6 different people: 3 male, 3 female) and side of marked hand (2: left, right).  Resulting in 384 trials and 24 repetitions for each critical condition (collapsing across marked hand and identity but not sex).

4. Interaction between Facing Direction and Stimulation Frequency - we expect to find a smaller difference in RTs between front- and back-facing stimuli in 10Hz stimulation group compared to 5.5Hz condition. If a significant interaction effect is found, follow up analysis will include pairwise t-test between 10Hz and 5.5Hz groups of the mean difference in RTs between front- and back-facing stimuli. 

5. Interaction between Sex and Facing Direction – we expect to find a greater difference in  RTs of back minus front-facing stimuli in the matched condition compared to mismatched.  If a significant interaction effect is found, follow up analysis will include pairwise t-test between mean RTs of congruent and incongruent conditions. 

6. Interaction between Sex, Facing Direction and Stimulation – we expect to find no greater difference between RTs of congruent conditions in 10Hz compared to 5.5Hz. 
Follow up analyses will include two 2x2 ANOVAs of Sex and Facing Direction, separately for 10Hz and 5.5Hz. We expect to find a significant interaction in 10Hz and not in 5.5Hz. In 10Hz, the 2x2 interaction will be followed up by a pairwise t-test between the front minus back differences in RTs of congruent and incongruent conditions. 

7. Interaction between AQ score and facing direction - we expect to find slower reaction times for back-facing stimuli and a smaller difference between back and front-facing stimuli RTs across both groups associated with higher AQ scores. However, it should be noted that our participants are assumed to be neurotypical and therefore not much variability in AQ scores is anticipated. 

8. A Correlation between AQ score and RTs - AQ scores will have an effect on RTs. We expect to find a smaller difference in RTs between front and back facing-stimuli as the AQ score increases. Separate to the factorial design we will measure the correlation between AQ scores and front-back RTs for each individual group and across both groups.

attributes.title: Investigating Body Satisfaction, Ideals and Concerns surrounding Femininity in Female Rugby Players

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Investigating Body Satisfaction, Ideals and Concerns surrounding  Femininity in Female Rugby Players.

other.value:
In the collection of basic demographic information, there will be an option for the participant to disclose their sexual orientation, their relationship status and their ethnicity. The participant will be made aware that all data collected in this study will be anonymous, but also that disclosure of these factors is entirely optional, and is purely of interest to the researcher and driven by the literature on the topic area.

Literature has linked the above factors as having an effect on an individual’s body image.

sample.value:
For this study, 20 participants from a Women’s University Premier League team will be recruited. This will be done through reaching out to the team directly, and through the coaching team. The researchers have requested permission from the head coach, who provided a signed letter of consent, stating that they were happy for the researchers to reach out to the players, requiring that any participation in the study would not have any impact on the training schedules, performance or well-being of the players. 

Due to the rich data that is being obtained from the study, 20 participants can be deemed a satisfactory sample size, and is achievable without extending the study demographically.

analyses.value:
This study will be of a mixed method design. Due to sample size, a hierarchical regression will be conducted, incorporating all the variables into the model. If the correlations found suggest that assumptions are met for a mediation analysis, then a mediation analysis will be conducted. If data can be analysed for mediation, this will be done to test whether Body Composition (as a predictor) predicts Ideal Body Size (outcome variable), and if this is mediated by Body Satisfaction, as predicted in the hypothesis. 

Qualitative data will be analysed using thematic analysis to see if concerns around femininity reflect, or are in line, with views on Body Satisfaction and Ideals.

outliers.value:
In order to identify outliers within the data, summary descriptive statistics will be calculated for the data, investigating skewness and kurtosis. This is will provide a view of the distribution of data. From this, boxplots will be used to identify outliers and then further t-tests, with and without the outliers within the data will give an inclination of the impact the potential outliers have on the data. 

Exclusion criteria will state that individuals who have a past or current diagnosis of a body image or eating disorder will not be able to take part in the study. Individuals with electrical devices, such as pace makers, will also be excluded from the study, due to the Tanita scales relying on bio-impedance.

dependent.value:
The independent variable for this study will be the Body Composition of the participants.  Body composition will consist of body fat %, BMI and % muscle mass. This will be measured using Tanita Scales and stadiometer. Tanita Scales are a highly reliable tool used to measure body composition by sending a small electrical signal through the bottom of the feet and through the body. This is a painless, non-invasive method of body composition measurement. 

The dependent variable for this study is Ideal Body Size. Ideal Body Size will be measured using a computerised matrix-style task, wherein the participant will be asked to select their ideal body size from a matrix of images, varying along an X and Y Axis, with muscularity along one axis and body fat along another. Their scores will represent their ideal muscularity and body fat, in both X and Y co-ordinates. They will complete this task 10 times, and using the co-ordinates on the graph that they select, and average will be calculated and this will be their ideal body size score. The outcome variable for this design is two dimensional. 

Body Satisfaction will be the Mediating variable, and this will be will be measured using standardised questionnaires: The Drive for Muscularity Scale (McCreary, 2013) and The Body Appreciation Scale (Tylka, 2006). This will obviously produce two scores, in both Body Appreciation and Drive for Muscularity. It will be investigated whether the scores collapse into a single variable, but possible two different models need to be built to investigate these two components of body satisfaction independently.

Concerns around femininity will be explored using a semi-structured interview, and analysed qualitatively, suing thematic analysis.

conditions.value:
This will be a mixed-methods, single group design, using both quantitative and qualitative research techniques, with no control or comparison groups and no manipulation of the independent variable. 

All participants will be subject to the same procedure, with no experimental control from the researcher.

hypothesis.value:
The aim of the study will be to investigate whether body composition predicts ideal body size in female rugby players. A mediation model will be tested with  body composition as a predictor, ideal body size as an outcome variable, and body satisfaction as a mediator to investigate whether body satisfaction is in fact an underlying mechanism in the relationship between body composition and ideal body size. 

There will also be a qualitative investigation into concerns surrounding femininity in this population and whether this has an influence on subjective perceptions of body image. This is due to there being a consistent theme throughout the literature in female athletes feeling that concerns around femininity affect the way they perceive their bodies. 

It has been well established that the female athlete population is often susceptible to the effects of body image concerns. However, a lot of this research focusses on the body ideals and concerns of “aesthetic” sports, such as dancing, swimming or gymnastics, and less on those of “non-aesthetic” or contact sports, such as rugby. This study will be taking a novel approach to body image research in female athlete samples, investigating a population where the physical demands of the sport require more focus on the strength and power in one’s body and increased size muscle mass is seen as an advantage. This is atypical from the standard female body ideal. 

Based on the existing literature, it is hypothesised that body composition will predict the ideal body size in female rugby players and that body satisfaction will mediate this relationship. There will be a positive relationship between body composition and discrepancy in their own body size and their ideal, but this will also be mediated by body satisfaction, depicted by scores on a questionnaire.

Participants within the sample who have more lean body compositions will have a smaller discrepancy between their actual body composition and their ideal body size, compared to those within the group who have larger body compositions, and again, this will also be mediated by body satisfaction.

attributes.title: The distribution of metacognitive resources during multi-tasking

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Confidence during multitasking: behaviour and pupilometry

other.value: Gaze data will also be collected from the eyetracker, but we do not have pre-registered analyses for this.

sample.value: Data will be collected from 30 participants. Excluded participants will be replaced.

analyses.value:
===========================================================================
Pupilometry preprocessing
===========================================================================
The preprocessing and analysis steps taken will be based on the steps taken in https://elifesciences.org/articles/18103 (Allen et al., 2016).

1. Eyetracking data will be timelocked to the onset of the RDK, and epoched from 250ms prior RDK onset to 250ms following RDK offset. 

2. Automatic blink correction will be performed by z-scoring pupil size in each epoch separately. Any time point where the absolute pupil size is greater than 2.5SD from the mean will be categorized as a blink. Linear interpolation over a 40 sample window around the blink (-20:20) will be performed. If this window extends to the end of the epoch, linear extrapolation will be performed instead. If more than 25% of the epoch is flagged for interpolation the trial will be removed from analysis.

3. Linear detrending using the matlab function 'detrend'

4. Low pass filtering using a 5 point moving mean

5. Manual artefact and blink detection. Trials flagged here will be removed from analysis. 

===========================================================================
Are the spatial allocations of processing and metacognitive resources correlated?
===========================================================================

For each participant, we will quantify their spatial allocation of processing as log( dprime_rdk / dprime_disc ).
For each participant, we will quantify their spatial allocation of metacognition as log( mratio_rdk / mratio_disc ).

To determine whether participants indeed prioritised the central RDK we compare log(dprime_rdk/dprime_disc) against 0 using a two-tailed t-test, predicting a value greater than zero [manipulation check].

To answer question one, we will compute a (two-tailed) spearman's rank correlation between  log(dprime_rdk/dprime_disc) and log(mratio_rdk/mratio_disc).

To analyse confidence ratings while controlling for accuracy, we will z-score confidence ratings separately for correct and incorrect trials. Then, we will pool trials back together and compute a two-tailed spearman's rank correlation between zconfidence_rdk/zconfidence_disc and mratio_rdk/mratio_disc. 
We cannot take logs here because z-transformed confidence will result in negative values.

===========================================================================
The relationship between confidence on the two tasks 
===========================================================================
Using the Matlab function fitlm, we will fit a linear regression model for each participant as follows:

zscore(confidence_disc) ~ b0 + b1*acc_disc + b2*acc_rdk + b3*confidence_rdk  ...
                                 + b4*acc_disc*acc_rdk ...
                                 + b5*acc_disc*confidence_rdk ...
                                 + b6*acc_rdk*confidence_rdk ...
                                 + b7*acc_disc*acc_rdk*confidence_rdk

Confidence_disc is z-scored to produce standardised betas.

Each beta coefficient (except b0) will be tested against 0 at the group level, using FDR to correct for multiple comparisons.

If confidence on the two tasks are correlated after controlling for accuracy, we should see a significant b3, b5, b6 or b7.

===========================================================================
Pupil size and confidence
===========================================================================

To reduce the multiple comparison burden, pupil data will be downsampled to 100 time points.

The variable sameAcc = acc_disc == acc_rdk will be computed.
The variable confDist  = log( conf_rdk/conf_disc) will be computed.

To examine whether pupil size is correlated with decisions in the task, we will fit the following regression model at each timepoint:

zscore(pupil_size)    ~ b0 + b1*acc_disc + b2*acc_rdk...
                                           + b3*motion_direction + ...
                                            + b4*confidence_disc  + b5*confidence_rdk ... 
                                            + b6*sameAcc ...
                                            + b7*confDist + ...
                                            + b8*acc_disc*confidence_disc ...
                                            + b9*acc_rdk*confidence_rdk

Pupil size is z-scored to produce standardised betas.

Data for group-level b1 and b2 values will be plotted but not analysed.

Data for group-level b0 and b3 will be neither plotted nor analysed.

For each time-point and each remaining beta (except b4-b9) will be tested at the group level against 0. The FDR method will be used to correct for multiple comparisons.

b4 and b9  have been previously shown to correlate with pupil size.
We are a priori predict that b7 will be significantly different from 0. 

===========================================================================

outliers.value:
(1) Participants with d_RDK less than or equal to 0 will be excluded
(2) Participants with d_disc less than or equal to 0 will be excluded
(3) Participants with mratio_RDK less than or equal to 0 will be excluded
(4) Participants with mratio_disc less than or equal to 0 will be excluded
(5) Participants who do not complete all trials will be excluded
(6) Participants with no variability in their RDK confidence will be excluded
(7) Participants with no variability in their disc confidence will be excluded
(8) Participants with fewer than 100 usable pupilometry trials will be excluded (from all analyses)

dependent.value:
*Subject-wise DVs*
(1) Type 1 d' (zHR - zFAR) for the RDK and for the disc discrimination task
(2) Mean confidence for the RDK and for the disc discrimination task
(3) m-ratio for the RDK and for the disc discrimination task (estimated using padding of 0.5 and Maniscalco & Lau's 2015 MLE code)

Our key DVs are:
- log( d_RDK / d_disc), which is positive when d' is higher for the RDK task and negative when it's higher for the disc task
- log( mratio_RDK / mratio_disc), which is positive when m-ratio is higher for the RDK task and negative when it's higher for the disc task

*Trial-wise DVs (for each of the central and peripheral task)*
(1) Correct vs. Incorrect 
(2) Confidence rating
(3) Proportion of samples (time) in which gaze was within 1 dva of the RDK bounding box
(4) Proportion of samples (time)  in which gaze was within a 1 dva radius of the peripheral bisected disc

conditions.value: There is only one condition: all participants perform 250 trials, in which they make a motion discrimination report with confidence on a central RDK and a binary object discrimination report with confidence on a peripheral bisected disc.

hypothesis.value:
This is a pre-registration for an exploratory study.

We are asking how subjective decision confidence and metacognitive sensitivity are distributed under shared attention.

                                            + b7*confDist + ...
                                            + b8*acc_disc*confidence_disc ...
                                            + b9*acc_rdk*confidence_rdk

Pupil size is z-scored to produce standardised betas.

Data for group-level b1 and b2 values will be plotted but not analysed.

Data for group-level b0 and b3 will be neither plotted nor analysed.

b4 and b9  have been previously shown to correlate with pupil size.
We are a priori predict that b7 will be significantly different from 0. 

===========================================================================

registration_responses.conditions: There is only one condition: all participants perform 250 trials, in which they make a motion discrimination report with confidence on a central RDK and a binary object discrimination report with confidence on a peripheral bisected disc.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
This is a pre-registration for an exploratory study.

We are asking how subjective decision confidence and metacognitive sensitivity are distributed under shared attention.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: Experiment I & II: An a priori power analysis with a power of 0.80 and medium effect size (f=0.25) calculated using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lan, & Buchner, 2007) indicates that a sample of 86 participants is needed for each experiment.

analyses.value: Experiment I & II: Our main interest is in analysing the fluctuation in participants’ beliefs in dissociative amnesia. For that reason, we will be conducting a 2 (dissociative amnesia video vs. control video) x 3 (time 1 vs. time 2 vs. time 3) mixed analysis of variance (ANOVA).

dependent.value: Experiment I & II: The dependent variable will be participants’ beliefs in dissociative amnesia measured through a 30-items questionnaire.

conditions.value: Experiment I & II: The current studies will use a 2 (dissociative amnesia video vs. control video) x 3 (time 1 vs. time 2 vs. time 3) mixed design with the last factor manipulated within-subjects.

hypothesis.value:
Experiment I: We will expose some participants to a video concerning a young woman talking about her dissociative amnesic experience vs. a control video (between-subjects). We expect that participants exposed to the first video (i.e., dissociative amnesia) will increase their beliefs in dissociative amnesia and related concepts as compared with participants who will be instead shown a control video.

Experiment II: We will expose some participants to a video concerning a university researcher who will critically speak about dissociative amnesia vs. a control video (between-subjects). We expect that participants exposed to the first video (i.e., dissociative amnesia) will decrease their beliefs in dissociative amnesia and related concepts as compared with participants who will be instead shown a control video.

registration_responses.name: Beliefs in Dissociative Amnesia
